      • scaleCircle1

        public void scaleCircle1()
        Error was discovered by test scaleCircle1 For Circle1 with radius of 3, scale by 0.8 expected a new radius of 2.4. Test failed because method scale(double) calculated factor incorrectly. Factor was added instead of being multiplied to radius. Running the test also resulted in a double rounding error. multiplying 3 by 0.8 produced the double 2.4000000000000004 instead of 2.4 Computation corrected: the option chosen to correct the error was to use the BigDecimal class and set precision to DECIMAL32 (7 digits).

      • scaleCircle2

        public void scaleCircle2()
        Error was discovered by test scaleCircle2. For Circle2 with radius of 2, scale by 2.8 expected a new radius of 5.6. Test failed because method scale(double) calculated factor incorrectly. Factor was added instead of being multiplied to radius. Computation corrected: the option chosen to correct the error was to use the BigDecimal class and set precision to DECIMAL32 (7 digits).

      • intersectCircle1

        public void intersectCircle1()
        Error was discovered by test intersectCircle1 If two circles have their centers at the same x, have radius 3 and their centers are 5 units apart, there should still be an overlap that is 1 unit wide from center to center. Since circle1 and circle1a have the same y value, their x values are 1 and 6. The difference is only 5. The radius of each circle is 3. It is expected that the two circles interset. Computation corrected to the pythagoreon theorem If a = distance from x1 to x2 (x2-x1) and b = distance from y1 to y2 (y2-y1), and if c is the distance from (x1,y1) to (x2,y2), which is the distance from the center of 1 circle to the center of the second circle, then c = sqrt(pow(a,2) + pow(b,2)) and the circles intersect if c less than (radius2 + radius1)

      • intersectCircle2

        public void intersectCircle2()
        Error was discovered by test intersectCircle2 If two circles have the same radius, 2, then the circles intersect so long as the distance between their centers is not twice the radius. In this case, the circle centers were 3 units apart while the value of twice their radius is 4 units, the intersects method should have returned true. Computation corrected. The calculated distance between the circles was compared only to the radius of one circle, not the combined radius of both circles.
